title: Logistic Regression, Target Prediction
input: Select a variable (numeric) to designate input values
passFail: Select a variable (category), e.g., Pass/Fail or a variable with 0/1 value
passValue: Type in the categorical value to be used as Pass/OK
label1: Select whether to compute probability from input value or input value from probability
useTargetProAspLBChk: Estimate Input using the above target probability (Reliability) as lower confidence bound
overlayObservedDataChk: Overlay observed pass/ok/success as points per input value group on the plot
overlayObservedDataConnectLineChk: A line to connect the verlay observed points per input value group
drawVerticalRefLineMaxInputValueChk: Draw a vertical reference line to show the min and max input value in the observed data
printPassRateTableChk: Print the pass rate (from the observed data) table
printModelDetailsChkChk: Print the underlying Logistic Model summary
verticalJustificationOffsetTargetInputVa: Control the vertical justification of the label for target input value
verticalJustificationOffsetMaxInputValue: Control the vertical justification of the label for min and max input value
digits: Digits to display in the output tables

help.title: Logistic Regression, Target Prediction
help.body:
Description
Binary Logistic Regression (Observed vs Fitted S-Curve)

Purpose
This analysis models and visualizes the relationship between a numeric input (e.g., Measurement) and a binary inspection result (e.g., Pass/Fail) using logistic regression. It estimates the probability of passing at different input levels and allows users to explore target reliability or input thresholds.It fits a binary logistic regression to model Pass/Fail vs. input measurement. It displays an S-curve with observed pass rates, fitted probability curve, and confidence band. It allows estimating reliability at a target input or input at a target reliability.

User Inputs
Dataset: Select the dataset containing the variables.
Input (X Variable): Continuous measurement or predictor variable.
Inspection (Y Variable): Categorical outcome with exactly two levels (e.g., Pass, Fail).
Pass Value String: The text value that represents a Pass (e.g., "Pass", “Good”, "OK").
Target Probability: Probability of passing (e.g., 0.999) to find the corresponding input value.
Target Input: Input value (e.g., 535) to estimate its reliability probability.
Confidence Level: Confidence interval width for predicted and inverse-predicted values (default 0.95).
Decimal Digits: Number of digits to display in numeric results.

Outputs
Plot: Observed vs Fitted S-Curve
Blue Curve: Fitted logistic regression probability of passing.
Shaded Area: Confidence interval for the fitted curve.
Black Dots: Observed pass rates per input (dot size ∝ number of observations).
Green Line: Maximum observed input in the dataset.
Red Line: Target input (if specified) with optional extrapolation label.

Tables
Observed Pass Rates: Pass rate, sample size, and input value.
Predicted Reliability from Input: Estimated and CI values for user-specified target input.
Estimated Input from Reliability Target: Input value corresponding to a target probability, with confidence limits.
Model Summary: Coefficients, standard errors, significance, and fitted model equation.

Interpretation
The S-curve shows how the probability of passing changes with input.
A steeper curve indicates a stronger relationship between measurement and inspection outcome.
Use the target input line to assess if the required measurement achieves the desired reliability.
If the curve is nearly flat, the input has little predictive influence.
